summary: A letter from attorney Kenneth W. Starr to the Principal Associate Deputy Attorney General arguing against federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. The letter claims prosecutorial misconduct, violations of a non-prosecution agreement, and that the case lacks proper federal jurisdiction, suggesting Epstein is only targeted due to his wealth and association with Bill Clinton.

persons.name: Kenneth W. Starr
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Jeffrey Epstein and arguing to the DOJ that federal prosecution is unwarranted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the potential federal prosecution. The letter argues the case against him is weak, driven by improper motives, and violates a prior non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as having a personal relationship with Epstein, including a trip to Africa on Epstein's plane. The letter suggests Epstein's notoriety from this association is a motive for prosecution.

persons.name: A. Oosterbaan
persons.context: Author of a May 15, 2008 letter referenced by Starr regarding the DOJ's prior review of the Epstein matter.

connections.description: Starr is the legal representative writing to the DOJ to argue against prosecuting his client, Epstein.
Described as having a personal relationship, including a well-publicized trip to Africa on Epstein's airplane.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office, which included suspending the federal grand jury investigation.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena Date
events.description: A new grand jury subpoena issued by an AUSA directs a witness to appear and give testimony, which Starr claims violates the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: DOJ Review Letter
events.description: A. Oosterbaan's letter states the Department's prior review of the Epstein matter was incomplete and not 'de novo'.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense claims the U.S. Attorney's Office violated a September 24, 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement by re-initiating a grand jury investigation in June 2008.
The letter alleges prosecutorial misconduct, including unauthorized leaks to the New York Times and an AUSA attempting to steer legal business to friends.

Starr argues the federal case is weak, lacks essential elements (like internet luring or interstate travel for illicit purpose), and is pursued only because of Epstein's wealth and ties to Bill Clinton.
The defense claims to possess statements from three principal accusers who deny the essential elements needed for a federal prosecution.
The letter requests a truly 'de novo' review by the DOJ, alleging the prior review was not independent and failed to consider exculpatory evidence.
